journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Demographic Trends in Arthroscopic SLAP Repair in the United States

article-meta.aff: *Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA, Los Angeles, California
Investigation performed at the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA, Los Angeles, California

author-notes.corresp: †Seth C. Gamradt, MD, Orthopaedic Surgery and Sports Medicine, David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA, 10833 Leconte Ave, CHS 76-139, Los Angeles, CA 90095 (sgamradt@mednet.ucla.edu).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

abstract.p: Background: Treatment of superior labral anterior posterior (SLAP) tears remains controversial, particularly in older age groups. Repair, debridement, biceps tenodesis, tenotomy, and observation have been recommended depending on patient characteristics, but there have not been any large epidemiologic studies investigating treatment trends.
Purpose: To investigate current trends in SLAP repair across time, gender, age, and regions in the United States.

Methods: Patients who underwent arthroscopic SLAP repair (Current Procedural Terminology [CPT] code 29807) were identified using a publicly available national database of insurance records (PearlDiver Patient Records Database) during years 2004 through 2009. Factors identified for each patient included gender, age group, and region in the United States. Logistic regression analysis and the chi-square test were used for statistical measures.

Results: From 2004 to 2009 there were 25,574 cases of arthroscopic SLAP repair identified, of which 75% were male patients and 25% were female patients. There was a significant rise in cases of SLAP repair from 2004 to 2009 as the incidence of SLAP repair increased from 17.0 for every 10,000 patients with an orthopaedic International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision (ICD-9) or CPT code in 2004 to 28.1 in 2009 (P < .0001). Age analysis revealed the highest incidence in the 20-29–year (29.1 per 10,000) and 40-49–year (27.8 per 10,000) age groups. Men (37.3 per 10,000) had a significantly higher incidence of repairs than did women (10.7 per 10,000). The West (24.6 per 10,000) and South (24.4 per 10,000) regions also demonstrated a higher incidence than the Midwest (20.5 per 10,000) and Northeast (20.1 per 10,000) regions (P < .0001).

Conclusion: Our analysis illustrates that surgeons are performing significantly more arthroscopic SLAP repairs each year. The highest incidence of repair is in the 20-29– and 40-49–year age groups, and a significant gender difference exists, with men having a threefold higher incidence of repair.

body.p: Superior labral anterior posterior (SLAP) tears were first described by Andrews et al2 in 1985 and later classified into 4 types by Snyder et al.22 Although it is a relatively rare entity,10,12,21 with the largest study by Snyder et al21 showing a prevalence of 6% in 2375 shoulder arthroscopic procedures, SLAP lesions can contribute to significant pain and disability in the shoulder.15,16,22 Advances in arthroscopic repair techniques have resulted in improved outcomes in certain patients.5,7,11,18,23,24,27 However, controversy exists about the optimal treatment of SLAP tears. Depending on patient age and activity level, it has been debated whether arthroscopic repair, debridement, biceps tenodesis, tenotomy, or solely observation should be performed, especially in the setting of concomitant injury.1,3,4,8,14,17

Despite a lack of consensus on the proper treatment of the SLAP lesion, there is recent evidence that the frequency of SLAP repair is on the rise.25 Weber et al25 analyzed 4975 cases of SLAP repairs collected from the American Board of Orthopaedic Surgery (ABOS) Boards Part II and found that ABOS candidates were performing SLAP repairs at a rate 3 times higher than expected, with an average patient age of 37 years. A detailed literature search yielded no other studies characterizing demographics of patients receiving SLAP repairs.

These findings demonstrate the need for an epidemiologic analysis of the current trends in arthroscopic SLAP repair from a large cross-sectional sample of the population. Awareness of these trends is important not only to the affected patient but also to the orthopaedic and health care community. The purpose of this study is to investigate current trends in SLAP repair across time, gender, age, and regions in the United States.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We used the PearlDiver Patient Record Database (www.pearldiverinc.com; PearlDiver Inc, Fort Wayne, Indiana) to query for patients with Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) code 29807 (arthroscopic SLAP repair) from 2004 through 2009. This is a publicly available national database of insurance billing records that can be used to search for patients who have had any orthopaedic International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision (ICD-9) or CPT code.6 The patients were stratified by year of surgery (2004-2009), age, gender, and region in the United States (South, West, Northeast, Midwest).

We chose the PearlDiver database for this study because it is formed through record collections across all age groups from multiple private payer insurance agencies, the largest contribution of which is from the UnitedHealth Group (www.unitedhealthgroup.com; UnitedHealth Group Inc, Minnetonka, Minnesota). The database specifically gathered ICD-9 and CPT codes related to orthopaedic diagnoses and procedures. Currently, it is composed of a verified collection of more than 216 million individual patient records on more than 11 million patients from the years 2004 through 2009. Further characterization of the database population through direct contact with PearlDiver Inc is listed in Tables 1 through 4 in the Appendix (available in the online version of this article at http://ajs.sagepub.com/supplemental/), including stratification by age, gender, region, and year. We used the number of database patients in each category from these tables to normalize the incidence of SLAP repair for the demographic analyzed.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Total Patients column represents the patient sample size of the database for that year, gender, or region, which totals to 11,153,039 for each demographic. Total SLAP column represents the incidence of SLAP repair CPT codes collected, which totals to 25,574 for each demographic. Normalized incidence of SLAP repair is calculated as ratio of SLAP repair cases per 10,000 patients with an orthopaedic ICD-9 or CPT code in that demographic. SLAP, superior labral anterior posterior.

sec.p: We used logistic regression analysis and the χ2 test to determine significance of distributions between the 4 stratifications. We used χ2 analysis when evaluating distributions in each category, such as age, gender, or region. When further determining significant differences in trends, such as yearly increase of SLAP repairs, we used logistic regression analysis. Significance was set for all analyses to P value less than .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of the 11,153,039 patients with an orthopaedic ICD-9 or CPT code included in the PearlDiver Patient Record Database from 2004 through 2009, there were 25,574 cases of arthroscopic SLAP repair. There was a significant increase in the number of annual SLAP repairs, with the 2654 cases in 2004 increasing by 105% to 5419 cases in 2009 (Figure 1). In 2004, the incidence of SLAP repair when normalized to patients from that year was 17.0 cases per 10,000 patients with an orthopaedic ICD-9 or CPT code (Table 1). This incidence increased to 28.1 cases per 10,000 patients with an orthopaedic ICD-9 or CPT code in 2009 (Table 1). Logistic regression analysis revealed P < .0001.

caption.p: Annual incidence of superior labral anterior posterior (SLAP) repair, with a total of 25,574 cases.

sec.p: Analysis of age distribution from 2004 through 2009 revealed 2674 cases in the 10-19–year age group, 3092 in the 20-29–year, 4787 in the 30-39–year, 7186 in the 40-49–year, 6178 in the 50-59–year, and 1619 in the 60-69–year age group. Even though there were a greater number of cases from the 40-59–year age range, when normalized to the age distribution of patients in the database (Appendix Table 1, available online), the incidence in 40- to 59-year-olds was similar to that in 10- to 29-year-olds (Figure 2). The highest incidence of SLAP repair was found in the 20-29–year (29.1 per 10,000) and 40-49–year (27.8 per 10,000) age groups, and χ2 analysis revealed P < .0001.

caption.p: Incidence of superior labral anterior posterior (SLAP) repair by age group for years 2004 through 2009. Results are normalized to cases per 10,000 patients with an orthopaedic International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision, or Current Procedural Terminology code.

sec.p: When analyzed for gender, 19,150 (75%) repairs were performed in male patients, and 6424 (25%) were performed in female patients. When normalized to the gender distribution in the database of 46% men and 54% women (Appendix Table 2, available online), this resulted in an incidence of more than 3 times higher in men (37.3 per 10,000) than in women (10.7 per 10,000) (Table 1). Chi-square analysis again illustrated significance for each group (P < .0001).

Regional analysis revealed the normalized incidence of SLAP repair to be highest in the West (24.6 per 10,000), followed closely by the South (24.4 per 10,000) (Table 1). Chi-square analysis revealed these regions to have a significantly higher incidence than the Midwest (20.5 per 10,000) and Northeast (20.1 per 10,000) regions (Table 1).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to report current trends in incidence of SLAP repair as well as demographics such as the age, region, and gender of these patients. Our data show that the incidence of SLAP repair is rising. There was a 105% increase in SLAP repair over a period of 6 years. This trend correlated to that seen by Weber et al25 using data from the ABOS Boards Part II. This report analyzed 4975 cases of SLAP repairs and found that ABOS candidates were performing SLAP repairs at a rate 3 times higher than expected, with an average patient age of 37 years. In conjunction, our study also showed a higher-than-expected incidence of repairs in older patients, as those in the 40-59–year age range had a similar incidence to those in the 10-29–year range.

The comparable incidence between these 2 age groups is unexpected as there is still significant controversy over SLAP lesion treatment, especially in patients of the older age range. Evidence-based medicine regarding SLAP repair consists largely of levels 3 and 4 case series of arthroscopic repair of type 2 SLAP tears,9,16 and successful nonoperative treatment of SLAP tears has been documented.3 However, proponents of SLAP repair in the older population point toward 2 studies in which SLAP repair with suture anchors was successful in those older than 40 years.1,17 Neri et al17 and Alpert et al1 showed no significant difference in patient satisfaction for patients older than 40 years and those younger than 40 years after a SLAP repair with suture anchors. Those calling into question the necessity or wisdom of SLAP repair in the older patient often cite Franceschi et al,8 who performed a randomized controlled trial comparing SLAP repair with tenotomy in the setting of arthroscopic rotator cuff repair; the authors found improved outcome scores in the tenotomy group. Boileau et al4 evaluated SLAP repair versus arthroscopic biceps tenodesis and found improved results in the tenodesis group, with improved return to activity and less revision surgery. Further clinical trials are needed to investigate the outcomes of SLAP repair versus biceps tenodesis, tenotomy, debridement, or observation, as the demographic trend revealed in our study indicates that the incidence of SLAP repair is continuing to rise and the older population is receiving repairs at rates equivalent to those of the younger population.

Gender may also play a role in the treatment of SLAP repairs. Our study demonstrates that men are more likely than women (3:1 ratio) to receive SLAP repairs, which is consistent with the Weber et al25 study that showed 78% of their patients to be male. Although in these types of studies selection bias can occur, the database distribution of 46% men and 54% women in our study indicated that there was no selection bias involved in men having more SLAP repairs. The significance of this gender difference is unclear. It is not known whether SLAP tears are 3 times as likely to occur in men or if surgeon preference is to repair more SLAP tears in men when encountered arthroscopically. Further, SLAP tears can occur due to acute trauma or the repetitive trauma associated with overhead athletics.13,19,20,26 It is possible that this trend reflects a differential exposure to trauma and/or sporting activities undertaken by men compared with women. Future investigations on biomechanical or clinical causes of this significant gender difference in SLAP repair are needed.

Regional analysis revealed a previously unreported statistically significant higher incidence of repairs in the West and South regions compared with the Midwest and Northeast regions. It is difficult to extrapolate a reason for this difference, as we cannot determine if there were more SLAP tears observed in the West and South or if the Midwest and Northeast had more cases of tenodesis, tenotomy, or observation that caused it to have a lower incidence of repair. Clearly, further comparative studies are necessary to determine the nature of the demographic trend identified in this regional analysis of the United States.

One limitation of this study is that the specific patient population included in the database may cause selection bias, as it is not a true cross-section of the US population and the South is overrepresented. The regional disparity of the database is likely a reflection of the distribution of patients carrying the UnitedHealth Group insurance plan, as this was the private payer group with the majority contribution of patient records. Further, we did not determine the number of patients in the database with an ICD-9 diagnosis of SLAP tear, so the increase in incidence of SLAP repair may be confounded by a higher incidence of SLAP tears. In addition, since epidemiologic data specifically addressing arthroscopic shoulder surgery are very sparse, there is not a comparable study by which to evaluate historical trends. The short duration of the data collection period of 6 years may have also limited the study. With a longer collection period, further details and variations for each trend may be better elicited. We did not determine if each procedure was performed by a sports medicine specialist versus a general orthopaedist, whether the repair was performed on the dominant arm versus nondominant arm, or if there were any concomitant procedures performed with the SLAP repairs. Further, the possibility of physician miscoding may have biased the outcomes. Evaluating these factors are all goals of future research.

In conclusion, our analysis indicates that the incidence of arthroscopic SLAP repair is increasing on a yearly basis. Patients in the 40-59–year age range have a similar incidence of repairs as patients in the 10-29–year range, and gender analysis shows that men have an incidence rate more than 3 times that of women. Finally, the West and South regions of the United States have a higher incidence of SLAP repair than do the Midwest and Northeast regions. Future studies evaluating the natural history and clinical outcomes of SLAP tears treated operatively and nonoperatively are needed to better elucidate the clinical effects of the demographic trends identified in this study.

fn.p: One or more of the authors has declared the following potential conflict of interest or source of funding: Dr Wang has stock holdings in PearlDiver Inc, which is the database used in this study.
